name.value: Naseljenici ostrva Katan / Насељеници острва Катан
นักบุกเบิกแห่ง Catan
カタンの開拓者たち スタンダード版

item.description:
In CATAN (formerly The Settlers of Catan), players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine which resources the island produces. Players build structures by 'spending' resources (sheep, wheat, wood, brick and ore) which are represented by the relevant resource cards; each land type, with the exception of the unproductive desert, produces a specific resource: hills produce brick, forests produce wood, mountains produce ore, fields produce wheat, and pastures produce sheep.

Set-up includes randomly placing large hexagonal tiles (each depicting one of the five resource-producing terrain types--or the desert) in a honeycomb shape and surrounding them with water tiles, some of which contain ports of exchange. A number disk, the value of which will correspond to the roll of two 6-sided dice, are placed on each terrain tile. Each player is given two settlements (think: houses) and roads (sticks) which are placed on intersections and borders of the terrain tiles. Players collect a hand of resource cards based on which terrain tiles their last-placed settlement is adjacent to. A robber pawn is placed on the desert tile.

A turn consists of rolling the dice, collecting resource cards based on this dice roll and the position of settlements (or upgraded cities—think: hotels), turning in resource cards (if possible and desired) for improvements, trading cards at a port, possibly playing a development card, or trading resource cards with other players. If the dice roll is a 7, the active player moves the robber to a new terrain tile and steals a resource card from another player who has a settlement adjacent to that tile.

Points are accumulated by building settlements and cities, having the longest road or the largest army (from some of the development cards), and gathering certain development cards that simply award victory points. When a player has gathered 10 points (some of which may be held in secret), s/he announces this and claims the win.

comment.value: It has a good, quick pace, and works well with three players. Too much luck, not enough strategy though. The best part of the game is picking your initial settlements. ---- (bought)
Too much luck. A bit too simple to spark interest.
na stanie

BASE GAME: Settlers of Catan (4th edition) 2007 SLEEVED[IMG]https://cf.geekdo-static.com/mbs/mb_5855_0.gif[/IMG] *Expansions are NOT sleeved yet OWN EXPANSION(s): EXPANSION: 5-6 Player Base Game EXPANSION: Cites & Knights (in Base Box) 1-4p EXPANSION: Explorers and Pirates (in it's own Box) 1-4p EXPANSION: Seafarers 1-4p EXPANSION: Traders & Barbarians (in Seafarers Box) 1-4 P MINi EXPANSIONS /PROMO: Catan: Event Cards (2005) CWC Berlin 2014 Special (2 tiles & The "Berlin Bear") Catan: Catan Day 2015 Exclusive Expansion (2015) Catan Scenarios: Helpers of Catan (2010) Catan Scenarios: Santa Claus (2015) Catan Geographies: Georgia EXTRA: Catan: Board (2-6 size) & handmade Card Holder EXTRAS In Custom Box: 45 Plastic Magnetic Hex tile holders Viking Themed Player Set for 6 players (boats for 1-4 in game) Extra BOATS 1-4 players from original set Cities and Knights ALL Wooden Player Set for 6 players 30 dark blue sea tiles with plain backs 12 plain colored hex tiles 36 wooden golden #1 peices 1 extra black robber, 1 extra black boat, 1 grey, 3 golden rood/house, 5 fire tokens, 5 ship tokens and 1 white disc

I was too young and/or too ignorant to get into this game when it first became all the rage in the mid-nineties. And when I finally got to play it, I just didn't care all that much about it - maybe it's because of the other, more refined games I'd learned to enjoy by then.

Bizarrely, my copy of this game, which I have had for over a year, is unplayed. Instead I've played on other people's sets at a local gaming club. Despite being quite a good player I have failed to ever win at this, and it is a source of personal frustration. Okay, its got a large random factor with the dice and a popularity/shouting factor with the trading and the cards throw an extra random element into the mix, but I should win sometime, surely....?

I would originally have rated this as a 9 but I'm bored with it now even with the numerous scenarios around. If the game lasts under an hour it's fine but you get the occassional one that just drags. However, I still think it's the perfect gateway game and will always select it when introducing newbies. I always preferred the Seafarers version but am quite happy with just the base game now. Cities & Knights tries to make the game something that it's not. Das Buch has some interesting scenarios though.
Отсутствует одна карточка МОНОПОЛИЯ.
Great when everyone is trading and manipulating each other for everything
Haven't played this one in years, and haven't played it since getting back into gaming.

I don't have any visceral hate for the game, I just wish it didn't take as long to play. One thing in particular that I dislike is similar to Terra Mystica; the critical decisions are all front loaded in the game (settlement placements and early expansion), and there is a permanence in the area/point controls. Catan just takes less time is the upside.

Perhaps I just over-played this one in its prime. Mostly, I just don't like games that take an hour and a half to play but you can often tell who's going to win in the first 30 minutes (or at least who is going to lose... but they're still stuck playing).

I like the game but the only problem I have with it is there is a lot of luck involved with the die role. Don't get me wrong, I like some luck in my games. But this one requires too much luck in order to win. For example, I played my 13 year old daughter and son and we all kept rolling 9s all of the time, which gave my daughter tons of resources. She clobbered us, getting 10 points before my son and I got to five points. I bought this game expecting a lot more strategy and was dissapointed. Edit: I have played this a few more times and, while I still don't see a ton of strategy in this game, I am seeing more possibilities. I think the expansions will probably go a long way toward increasing replayability. I increased the rating from a 7 to a 8. Edit 2: I got Cities and Knights and it makes this game a solid 9 for me. We're having a lot of fun with it!
Rachel's half

One of my favorite 4 player games. A fine mix of luck and strategy. You feel like you have quite a few options each turn and trading is awesome. Great replay value. Once you get comfortable with the game, I would recommend the cities and knights expansion.
Takes WAY too long for what it is.
Box says original title "The Settlers of Catan"

I feel it is far too complicated to be suggested as a gateway game. Ticket to ride and Carcassonne both are easier to introduce. Major strategy elements are decided in the first few minutes of play, making it incredibly unforgiving to newcomers.
Played heavily before I began tracking plays
An extremely simple and enjoyable game; but not quite as deep as those I usually enjoy.
My gateway game. It will always hold a special spot for me for that!

We were late to the game in playing Settlers and had already worked through Dominion and Carcassonne dozens of times before this one hit the table. We've played it once or twice, but with so many other great, and newer, games in our collection, there is no reason to ever play it. Still, it is one of the new classics.
Location: MSK
Uncommentable...
Highly luck depended. Even if you have a good position you may get slight resources because of a bandit or unstable dice rolls. The biggest problem is once you go down, you can never go up.
Like new, opened, never played
Finally thrifted a complete 3rd edition in great shape!
Cities & Knights Explorers & Pirates Seafarers Traders & Barbarians
Great game but not for me. I don't want to beg the other player for a log or some wool.
iOS version

I don't understand why everyone seems to like this game so much. It's made of good quality materials but the gameplay for me is just...bleh. I play it quite a bit however because it's one of the few games I can get my whole family to play.
A simple game that is different every time you play due to the random board and the people you are playing with.
Often the door in the board game world...
Plays and dates estimated.

While I appreciate its significance as a gateway game, I do not like how bad you can get screwed thanks to dicerolls. I also do not like the relative value of some of the starting town positions versus others. I hope that Anno 1701 gets printed in the US, to supplant Settlers as the gateway Catan game.
A gold standard for game balance, replayability, and pacing.
Not bad, but would not play it when there are other games around.

Excellent game to introduce new players to board games, especially because they might win (it happened in my last two games), but also because the rules are simple and fast to learn. Although I like it, it's too luck driven. If the dice don't like you, you won't stand a chance.
I love this game! It is near perfect. It plays well with 3, but really seems like a game for 2 couples. When we have 4 to play, it's Settlers at my house!

The metagame possibilities make this title great. If played properly with table talk, side deals, alliances, i.e. nothing explicitly stated in the rules, then this game really shines. In this style I'd rate it at an 8 or even 9 perhaps. On the other hand, if played strictly as a eurogame (which seems to be the majority of the time) it is merely okay in my opinion, I'd rate it at a 5.

The game's a masterpiece, even though I hate the dice rolling. The game that turned me on to German/designer games, as well as all of my friends. Don't play it much anymore, but it's definitely earned a permanent place in my all time top 10. Own the [boardgame=926]Cities & Knights[/boardgame], [boardgame=27760]Traders & Barbarians[/boardgame], [boardgame=135378]Explorers & Pirates[/boardgame], [boardgame=325]Seafarers[/boardgame] and [boardgame=86669]Helpers[/boardgame] expansions, as well as the [boardgame=189097]Santa Claus[/boardgame], [boardgame=131958]Frenemies[/boardgame], [boardgame=110794]Oil Springs[/boardgame], [boardgame=86669]Helpers of Catan[/boardgame] scenarios, and the [boardgame=167841]Wedding Tower[/boardgame] promo.
One of my first strategy board games. Loved it until I started discovering everything else out there.
You play Catan with your friends. Everyone trades resources. It's great.

I used to think this game was the greatest thing ever. But now I'm not too sure. Too random and luck based. I prefer my board games "German". As in no luck involved. Still a good game to introduce non gamers to a world of games out there that are a whole bunch of a lot better than Monopoly! For that it absolutly rocks!
Reviewed on my blog.
Any game that has win-win negotiating as the mechanic is ok by me
We never play the base version any more, but it's a nice intro to the hobby, I guess
2-4 Players
Unrecorded plays ~ 10
not a bad game, always plays too long with larger group, and there are just other more fun games to play
DEVIR Portuguese edition
Notes from the perspective of a Middle School Game Club: The length maxes out the club, but it is a solid choice. Gets a little boring for some students.
A little bit too simple without add-ons.
3–6 Players (Best: 4) Playing Time: 90–150 Min

The gateway game to modern board gaming. Harvest, trade , expand. One downside to the game is there is no combat system. A price laid is where a price stays. Still a legend of a game, but does get grown out of.

Purple metallic robber and metallic dice set from FanRoll - stored in base game Replacement black pawn robber - stored in base game Own 2 copies of 3rd edition. Also have a Settlers wooden game board, 1 set of 4th edition replacement cards and 2 longest turn (negative victory point) cards.
Bueno y sencillo
Classic! These hexes are so cute!
This is the gateway game. I'm almost always willing to play.
A game best served with inebriants for maximum 'Got wood?' value.
Nice game for family and friends, base building and trading and possible twists in ending score
Oldie goldie, we don't like the dice dependency, but we really enjoy the game
Not a huge Catan fan, but it's a newcomer's favorite so I had to add it to my collection.

If I'm going to play a Euro, it should be exciting, and Settlers is certainly that. The dice rolls really make the game--they let the drama of not getting what you need, of being forced to make new plans, rise up. My only complaint is that you can be out of the game before your first turn if your initial set up isn't well thought out. That is a huge barrier for new players versus experienced players, but the game seems to have done alright for itself. Certainly worthy of its status, and I don't understand why it isn't ranked higher.
IMO very easy and good game
I hid it somewhere.
Interactive with trading and the robber... but not strong mechanically. Too much depends on initial placement. But can be a fine game for non-hobby gamers.
เกมแรกที่ทำให้เข้าวงการ หลังๆออกแนวเฉยๆที่จะเล่น แต่ถ้าให้ดีต้องใช้ event การ์ดเท่านั้น ไม่ค่อยชอบทอยเต๋าเท่าไรล่ะใช้แล้วหดหู่

130929 The thrill of waiting to see the dice go your way gets a little old. But no denying its thrilling, as well as hoping your opponent doesn't do something. Maybe I like the tenseness of these games, but I don't like the source of the tenseness (the secretly hoping your opponent doesn't make a blocking play). 100808 Dice. Otherwise fun and thrilling, but the dice part kinda drives me nuts...
My introduction to modern boardgames.

The trading and resource gathering is interesting -- and it was a trailblazer -- but for many people, there are more interesting games out there. Look, Catan got me into gaming. I can't deny that I've loved and played it a lot. But Catan (especially with no expansions) just isn't interesting anymore. I have played it upwards of thirty times online against AIs, and as such I'm pretty much played out on the game. Diversify your hexes, go for largest army or longest road (whichever has less competition), and trade only as much as necessary. Spread out and diversify your resources early, then bulk up on cities mid-game. I don't know, strategies vary, but I just feel like I'm always playing Catan on rails. It feels solved. So yes, Catan is a great gateway game. It's exciting for new players who've never played a German-style game before. But I don't need to buy the game, or its expansions -- there's no need to. I've got plenty of other games that scratch that itch, and while I'm happy to recommend it, there's no need for me to personally own it.
I will only play Catan with certain groups
2015 május

My first impression is: this is the best family game in 20 years and that's before I even knew about BGG! After my eyes have been opened wide by BGG, I would still say this' the best family game in 20 years (over the likes of Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk) but my attention was diverted to those of Puerto Rico, Twilight Imperium III, and Android... Thus I brought down my grading for Catan to 8 from 10 as I would like to try out the others first (and the BGG grading is based on willingness to play). But my impression remained the same for Catan: it's the best family game in 20 years!
A great game for welcoming non-gamers to games. Simple, elegant game with excellent replayability, especially when you're incorporating the modularity of the Seafarers expansions.
Minority opinion: I don't like this as much as most people. Glad it started the German game craze though.
A classic.
My first "German style" game and I love it. Would love to play more, but need at least three people.

Personally I hate this game. Win or lose, I always feel like I had a bad time, either cause I stomped or got stomped. But occasionally you'll have that game where everyone rolls your numbers and you ride off into the sunset on a pile of bricks, wheat and sheep.
Catan is the first high end board game I played. It is a good, fun game, although it is a little dry.
Simple euro with good interaction and planning aspects. I enjoy playing this with my kids (ages 8 and 6).
A modern classic.
Very good game. If you fall behind early, it can be very boring though.

This was my introduction to European games, and it still stands as one of the very best. Short enough to get played often, but long enough to be satisfying. Simple enough to teach casual gamers to play (and they like and understand it), but still a very engaging and fun game. Has lots of decision making and player interaction, and requires a good mix of luck, strategy, and trading. Loving civilization-type games, I really like the way this one plays. Also, I made my own board, which makes it look awesome: www.boardgamegeek.com/image/152673
Trade interest low.
An all-time classic! One of the strategy games that led the board game industry to become what it is today.

One has to give credit for Catan for being a groundbraking game that paved the way for what modern boardgames are today. There is something appealing in the the theme, but games have evolved tremendously in the last decade and while groundbraking in the 90's, Catan simply falls short these days. Simply put, I find Catan to be an awful game of dice-rolling randomness that takes way too long to boot. It looks nicer than Monopoly, but gameplay-wise the latter is better.. and that's saying a lot, since it's not much of a game either. As a family game Catan might be passable, but it creates so much frustration that I doubt it would be much fun. Even the iPhone app is waste of money.. I would not play it unless I wanted to piss myself off on purpose.

This was my gateway game! Settlers was the first Euro style game I ever played...really the first nontraditional game ever for me, and ever since I've become obsessed! Still enjoy Settlers. I took to the mechanic instantly and still love to play.

Love it - will still play at any time. I love when a newbie to the hobby will gush about this "great new game called Settlers of Catan..." Oh, let me open your eyes! The gateway game. If they don't like it, give it up and find a new friend, lol.
[Estante 09] [m000156]
German language edition, wooden pieces

The GOAT - as a seasoned gamer I find it drags on a bit, and the strategies are somewhat limited (roads, cards, cities). However I'm always shocked at how well this goes as a gateway game, it seems to be just right in terms of complexity for people to pick it up, with enough randomness that nobody feels bad if they lose.
